title: The Black Rider (album)
text:
The Black Rider is the twelfth studio album by <a href="Tom%20Waits">Tom Waits</a>, released in 1993 on <a href="Island%20Records">Island Records</a>, featuring studio versions of songs Waits wrote for the play "<a href="The%20Black%20Rider">The Black Rider</a>", directed by <a href="Robert%20Wilson%20%28director%29">Robert Wilson</a> and co-written by <a href="William%20S.%20Burroughs">William S. Burroughs</a>. The play is based on the German folktale "<a href="Der%20Freisch%C3%BCtz">Der Freischütz</a>" by <a href="Johann%20August%20Apel">Johann August Apel</a>, which had previously been made into an <a href="opera">opera</a> by <a href="Carl%20Maria%20von%20Weber">Carl Maria von Weber</a>. The play premiered on March 31, 1990, at the <a href="Thalia%20Theater%20%28Hamburg%29">Thalia Theater</a> in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. Its world English-language premiere occurred in 1998 at the <a href="Edmonton%20International%20Fringe%20Festival">Edmonton International Fringe Festival</a>.
Waits would later collaborate with Wilson on the plays "Alice" (1992) and "<a href="Woyzeck">Woyzeck</a>" (2000), the music to which were released on the albums "<a href="Alice%20%28Tom%20Waits%20album%29">Alice</a>" and "<a href="Blood%20Money%20%28Tom%20Waits%20album%29">Blood Money</a>", respectively.
Track listing.
All songs written by Tom Waits, except where noted. Recorded in 1989 by Gerd Bessler at his Music Factory in Hamburg, Germany (2, 3, 6–9, 14–16, 19, 20), and in 1993 by <a href="Tchad%20Blake">Tchad Blake</a> and assisted by Joe Marquez at the Prairie Sun Recording Studios in <a href="Cotati%2C%20California">Cotati</a>, <a href="California">California</a> (1, 4, 5, 10–13, 17, 18). Musical Director Greg Cohen. All songs mixed by Biff Dawes At Sunset Sound Factory, Hollywood, CA.
Hans-Jörn Brandenburg, Volker Hemken, Henning Stoll, Christoph Moinian, Dieter Fischer, Jo Bauer, Frank Wulff, and Stefan Schäfer were The Devil's Rhubato Band (Hamburg); <a href="Ralph%20Carney">Ralph Carney</a>, Bill Douglas, Kenny Wollesen, Matt Brubeck, Joe Gore, Nick Phelps, Kevin Porter, Lawrence "Larry" Rhodes, Francis Thumm, Don Neely, Linda Deluca were The Rhubato West Group (<a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>).
Songs performed in the play, but not included on the album: "Chase the Clouds Away" and "In the Morning".
